importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the reporting of a major Amazon cloud outage, highlighting ongoing technological vulnerabilities in internet infrastructure.
The outage began early Monday morning, with recovery declared by 6 p.m. Eastern time on the same day, illustrating the timeline of a critical digital failure and repair process.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage started at 3:11 a.m. and was resolved by 6 p.m. Eastern time, emphasizing the duration and scale of disruption across global services.

keyTakeAways: The Amazon cloud outage disrupted a wide range of critical services, including social media, gaming, financial platforms, and educational tools like Canvas.
The outage was caused by issues in Amazon's Domain Name System (DNS), which translates web addresses into IP addresses, affecting how websites and apps load.
The incident underscores the world’s growing dependence on a small number of tech companies—particularly Amazon Web Services—for core internet infrastructure.
Services such as Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, and the McDonald’s app were impacted, with users reporting inability to access or use them.
Educational institutions such as the University of California, Riverside, and Ohio State University reported that students could not submit assignments, access materials, or take quizzes.
Amazon acknowledged that 64 internal services were affected, and recovery was gradual, with some areas experiencing intermittent glitches during restoration.
Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess noted that such outages are typically technical, not cyberattacks, and are common due to the centralized nature of cloud computing.
This is not the first time AWS has experienced major outages—similar incidents occurred in 2017, 2020, and 2021, with the 2021 outage lasting over five hours.
The recovery process is described as slow and bumpy, similar to a large-scale power outage, with some users still experiencing issues even after official restoration.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A massive outage of Amazon Web Services (AWS) in October 2025 disrupted internet services globally, affecting major platforms such as Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, and the McDonald’s app. The outage, which began at around 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and lasted into the afternoon, stemmed from issues in AWS’s Domain Name System (DNS), causing widespread failures in online services. Amazon reported that 64 internal services were impacted, and recovery was gradual, with full service restoration achieved by 6 p.m. Eastern time. The incident highlighted the world’s increasing dependence on a few major tech companies—especially AWS—for internet infrastructure, with educational institutions like the University of California, Riverside, and Ohio State University reporting significant disruptions to online learning. Experts note that such outages are typically technical, not cyberattacks, and are common due to cloud dependency, though they remain a reminder of the fragility of modern digital systems.
title: Amazon Cloud Outage Exposes Internet’s Vulnerable Backbone
